bibl.title: Letter from R.A. Watson to Mabel H. Lazear, April 4, 1907

div1.p: Watson writes that the New York Merchants' Association wants to work for a pension increase for her. He believes Lazear's work has been slighted.

div1.head: Letter from R.A. Watson to Mabel H. Lazear, April 4, 1907
div1.opener:
FRAME & CO.
_____
Telegraphic Addresses:
“ADVANCE, NEW YORK.”
“FRAMEZZO LONDON.”
ABC, AI & Lieber's Codes Used.
_____
ALSO AT
21 MINCING LANE, LONDON, E.C.
90-96 Wall Street,
New York, 4th.April 1907
Mrs. Jesse W. Lazear
Santa Barbara
Dear Madam,
div1.p:
Will you kindly pardon
me if inadvertently I may have
given you any offense in looking
into your private affairs.

I heard some little
time ago, of your late husbands
sacrifice in Cuba, and I was
led to believe you had been
left in difficult circumstances &
that while the United States Govt.
had given real aid to the
widow of one & wife of the other
officer who had aided in the
yellow fever tests, nothing had
been done for you.

I did not then
know your address or would
have written first to you, to
ask permission, before bringing
to the attention of the New
York Merchants Assn. the facts
as I believed them to be.
2
The Merchants Assn took up
your case in Washington, &
I am now led to believe
that if your circumstances
are not Comfortable they
will be made so, and I
am told, all recognize they
brave work of your husband
to have been the most
important of all.

If I have not
offended by taking up your
case without permission, &
should the facts be true
as related to me, as to
your present circumstances,
will you kindly tell me
just how you are situated,
as the Merchants Assn. have
asked me for this information
to guide them in claiming
for you a proper pension
